title: Can I file chapter 7 or 13 on the IRS
question: I owe more than $46,000 to the irs and i can no longer afford the payments I make to them
answers:
The question is whether you can file in your chapter 13 or 7 BK on the IRS.

The answer will always be YES. You have a duty to disclose and include all your assets and liabilities (including taxes) regardless of the dischargeability of those debts.

In chapter 7 or 13 the trick question is whether the "tax: will be considered priority or not.

The Bankruptcy Code does not specify taxes that are dischargeable. It specifies taxes that are excepted from discharge. Income taxes excepted from discharge are primarily addressed in Bankruptcy Code sections 507(a)(7)(A), 523(a)(1)(B) and 523 (a)(1)(C). In simple language, unless secured, income taxes are not excepted from discharge, and consequently are dischargeable if:

1. A return has been filed;
2. If filed, assessment was not based on fraud;
3. If filed late, the return was filed two years or more before the bankruptcy petition;
4. The tax return, with extensions, was due three years or more before filing of the bankruptcy petition; and
5. Tax liability was assessed more than 240 days before filing of the petition.

all five need to be met to be dischargeable.

Tax issues are complex in nature and $46,000 in taxes worth asking an attorney specialized in BK.

Try a bankruptcy attorney in your area. Look in the AVVO listing for Fresno and I am sure that you will not regret you did.

Good luck.

There are a set of criteria that needs to be met in order for a particular tax to be discharged in bankruptcy, such as whether three years have passed since the tax became due? have two years passed since you filed them? Have 240 days passed since they have been assessed? These, especially the last question, is not a simple yes or no question. This requires an experienced bankruptcy attorney to review your tax transcripts to see if there have been any assessments, whether the assessments have been tolled at all for any given time, and what other issues your particular taxes are facing. The difference between 'winging' this and going to an experienced bankruptcy attorney could be as simple as filing too early and not being able to discharge your tax debt.

If your debt to the IRS is more than 2 years old, there is a possibility that it may be dischargeable in a Chapter 7 bankruptcy. You will definitely need to contact an experienced bankruptcy lawyer to evaluate your unique circumstances.

Can it happen? Yes.

Would I trust a non-attorney to figure it out? No.

Get an attorney. The IRS is the worst creditor and make sure you are safe.

good luck.

Most definitely you need a good bankruptcy attorney to assist you. The rules are complex when considering the dischargeability of IRS debt. You cannot do this alone! Go to www.nacba.org attorney finder and get someone who can help you.

Whether a Chapter 7 Bankruptcy will discharge your obligation to the IRS can be a quite complicated matter. First, you need to determine whether you qualify for a Chapter 7. Second, discharging IRS debts in a Chapter will depend, upon other things, if your returns were filed timely, the years for which you the debts, whether amendments were required to any one return and whether these were filed, whether there was an audit.

Your situation is definitely one requiring the assistance of an experienced, local bankruptcy attorney. I would consult one right away.
